Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Minimally Invasive Interventional Radiological Techniques in Colorectal Cancer Metastases

Trial_Design.evidence: This randomised controlled trial was conducted at a tertiary care center.

Participants.evidence: Participants included patients with colorectal cancer liver metastases who were ineligible for surgical resection.

Intervention.evidence: The intervention group received portal vein embolization, radioembolization, or ablation, while the control group received standard chemotherapy.

Objective.evidence: This study evaluates minimally invasive interventional radiological techniques as alternatives.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the increase in future liver remnant volume (FLR) over 6 months.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was performed using a computer-generated sequence, with allocation concealment via sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was applied to outcome assessors.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 200 participants were randomised: 100 to the intervention group and 100 to the control group.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Analysis was conducted on 98 participants in the intervention group and 97 in the control group using an intention-to-treat approach.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The intervention group showed a significant increase in FLR (mean difference = 15%, 95% CI 10% to 20%; p < 0.001).

Harms.evidence: Adverse events were mild, with 5% in the intervention group and 3% in the control group experiencing minor complications.

Funding.evidence: Funding: Supported by the National Cancer Institute.
